G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u202f19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Boston Municipal Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the subject property is located within the City of Boston.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u202f410.201.proposition: The statutory minimum legal heat requirement in Massachusetts mandates that residential landlords maintain a temperature of at least 68°F from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. and at least 64°F at all other times.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that persistent heating failures constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.support_reasoning: The case discusses liability for interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant, but the facts and analysis concern repeated flooding and sewage, not heating failures. Nowhere does the opinion address lack of heat or heating failures as constituting a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it is authority that serious, repeated sanitary-code violations like flooding can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically recognize persistent heating failures as such a breach.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it … permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that persistent heating failures constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that a landlord’s failure to provide heat or related services can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so by citing earlier cases (e.g., Charles E. Burt and Shindler) as examples. Blackett itself concerns excessive noise from a bar as constructive eviction and a breach of quiet enjoyment, not persistent heating failures. Thus, it is indirect authority at best and does not itself establish that heating failures constitute such a breach.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). … Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933) (failure to install necessary heating system, as agreed).”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that persistent heating failures constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.” The court rejects financial inability as a defense and orders declaratory, injunctive, and damages relief under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for the heat failure. This squarely supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts recognize persistent heating failures as a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14…”

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.proposition: The duty of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to use the premises for the purposes for which they were rented, free from interference by the landlord.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly recognizes that a lease carries an implied obligation that the landlord refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises and the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment. It holds the landlord liable for authorizing work that, though outside the demised rooms and done reasonably, nonetheless interfered substantially with the plaintiff’s use of the premises for his dental practice. This aligns with the proposition that the duty of quiet enjoyment protects the tenant’s right to use the premises for the purposes rented, free from landlord interference.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises… the landlord is liable therefor…. It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants….”

*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.proposition: The duty of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to use the premises for the purposes for which they were rented, free from interference by the landlord.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, explaining that a landlord’s failure to provide an essential service that makes premises untenantable for their intended use can breach that covenant. It also later frames the landlord’s duties (in the dependent-covenants analysis) in terms of depriving the tenant of a substantial benefit significant to the purpose of the lease. While the holding ultimately rests on mutually dependent covenants rather than directly on quiet enjoyment, the discussion ties quiet enjoyment to protecting the tenant’s ability to use the premises for the purposes for which they were rented, free from landlord interference/failures to perform essential obligations.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.relevant_excerpt: “A constructive eviction is any ‘act of a permanent character, done by the landlord, or by his procurement, with the intention and effect of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment of the premises demised, or of a part thereof….’ … Thus, a landlord’s failure to provide a service that is essential to the use and enjoyment of the demised premises may qualify as a constructive eviction.… Yet, conduct that does ‘not make the premises untenantable for the purposes for which they were used’ will not constitute constructive eviction.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions—specifically, failure to provide consistent heat and disregard of recurring complaints—constitute constructive interference and a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses extensive habitability defects, lack of heat, harassment, and related conduct, and affirms liability on multiple theories including breach of the implied warranty of habitability, retaliation, and intentional infliction of emotional distress, with treble damages under Chapter 93A. However, the judgment explicitly dismisses the covenant of quiet enjoyment counterclaim to avoid cumulative damages and does not analyze or base its holding on constructive interference or a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment due to lack of heat. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that these acts and omissions constituted constructive interference and a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.relevant_excerpt: “Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims…. On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad’s intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress, and that such proof constituted a basis for recovery under c. 93A.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions—specifically, failure to provide consistent heat and disregard of recurring complaints—constitute constructive interference and a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself and without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court holds that at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know is required and that strict liability under the lead paint statute alone is insufficient. It does not involve failure to provide heat or recurring complaints, and it does not hold that such facts constitute constructive interference; rather, it clarifies the fault standard for § 14 claims generally.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Lis v. Mullen*, **5 Mass. App. Ct. 914*.proposition: The State Sanitary Code’s minimum standards for heat are enforceable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord fails to comply.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.proposition: The State Sanitary Code’s minimum standards for heat are enforceable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord fails to comply.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the landlord’s noncompliance with the State Sanitary Code minimum standards for heat and hot water to a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and holds that such a breach gives rise to rent abatement regardless of the landlord’s fault once the landlord has notice. The court states that the landlord must at least comply with the minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes and rejects attempts to contract around those Code-based obligations. This makes Code heat requirements enforceable through the warranty (and thus through rent abatement tied to quiet enjoyment-type interests).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. … The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151** (19.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was at least negligent and willful, given his continuing failure to remedy the defect after repeated notice.
*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151** (19.support_reasoning: The proposition speaks to a defendant’s conduct being at least negligent and willful for failing to remedy a *defect after repeated notice*. Leardi concerns the inclusion of deceptive lease provisions and the statutory consequences under G.L. c. 93A, including a discussion of ‘willful or knowing’ violations only in the abstract and a rejection of treble damages; it does not involve a physical defect, repeated notice of a defect, or a holding that continued non-remediation is negligent or willful. Thus it does not provide authority for that specific proposition.
*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151** (19.relevant_excerpt: “The Housing Court judge found that the landlord responded to the plaintiffs’ demand letter ‘in bad faith, with knowledge or reason to know that his insistence on including the challenged clauses in the tenants’ leases violated G. L. c. 93A, § 2.’ On this ground he awarded treble damages. Without reaching the issue of whether the defendants’ response was made in bad faith, we conclude that the judge erred in trebling the award of statutory damages.”
